title: What was Steve Jobs' IQ? - Quora

response.answer_text: Steve Jobs earned a 32 on the ACT at a time when a 24 is now equivalent to a 28. According to Mensa, a 29[1] at that time is still a qualifying score for membership so we can assume that’s in the neighborhood of 98th percentile. To earn a 32, I’d guess would be in the neighborhood of a 35 today, which is in the 99.6th percentile today[2]. The correlations between standardized tests and IQ were much higher than they were today. The *recently* old SAT had a correlation as high as .86[3]. Going by a conservative r of .82 from old ACT to IQ and a 99.5th percentile score we find: [math](0.82)*(.995i → 2.576 SD) = 2.112 SD =[/math] 132 [WAIS/WISC]151 [Cattel]134 [Stanford-Binet]A little bit a pseudo-data, but that’s a good lower bound for his IQ. Personally, I’d put him in the 140 - 150 [WAIS] range due to his financial success. There is a correlation between the two, but I think this gives you a good estimate already. Feel free to upvote and I’ll perform that calculation. EDIT: Due to the surprising number of upvotes, this is a breakdown of Steve Jobs’s IQ as predicted from financial success. At beginning of the year of his death, Steve Jobs was worth $8.3 Billion[4] “tying” him as the 110th richest person alive. The world population turned 7 billion at the end of the same year.[5] With that kind of rarity we find: [math]110/7,000,000,000 ≈ 0.99999998428i → 5.6535 SD[/math] Yes, “wow” We have two choices for r: A senior published meta-analysis[6]Two recent unpublished meta-analyses[7] [8]The first finds: [math](0.23)*(5.6535 SD) ≈ 1.3 SD[/math] 121 [WAIS/WISC]132 [Cattel]120 [Stanford-Binet]The second two (.49 & .48) find: [math](0.485)*(5.6535 SD) ≈ 2.74 SD[/math] 141 [WAIS/WISC]166 [Cattel]144 [Stanford-Binet]At these top tiers of net worth, the income is proportional to wealth. We have few kings hoarding their piles of treasure, sinking out of existence. Old Warren Buffett is as competitive as ever. Even the Arabian oil barons experience mildly-meritocratic intelligence selection: they continue to invest and expand into renewable technologies, etc. Obviously, the ratio isn’t solid; so take note of that. Steve Jobs was undoubtedly genius. Pristine intelligence is necessary to achieve innovation and success on a world scale. But… I think to myself of all the times Steve dropped acid, all of his adventures in India, the luck of his birth in The Valley, his astute emotional clairvoyance, and his dedication to merit. These are what made Steve Jobs, Steve Jobs. EDIT: grammar Footnotes[1] Qualifying test scores[2] How Many People Get a 34, 35, 36 on the ACT? Score Breakdown[3] https://www.psychologicalscience.org/pdf/ps/Frey.pdf?origin=publication_detail (https://www.psychologicalscience.org/pdf/ps/Frey.pdf?origin=publication_detail)[4] The World's Billionaires 2011 - Forbes.com[5] Day of Seven Billion - Wikipedia[6] http://www.emilkirkegaard.dk/en/wp-content/uploads/Intelligence-and-socioeconomic-success-A-meta-analytic-review-of-longitudinal-research.pdf[7] The incredible correlation between IQ & income[8] IQ and Permanent Income: Sizing Up the “IQ Paradox”

response.answer_text: Steve Jobs had an IQ of about 160+ (range: 150 to 178):  Steve Jobs likely had an IQ roughly 160 or above. In Walter Isaacson's biography,  near the end of 4th grade Jobs was tested. Jobs said: 'I scored at the  high school sophomore level.' This means he was a 4th grader performing  at the 10th grade level. The average 4th grader is 9 or 10 years old and  the average 10th grader is 15 or 16 years old. Using the standard mental age/chronological age x 100 = IQ formula,  we can create rough boundaries. Lower bound: 15/10 x 100 = 150 IQ.  Upper bound: 16/9 x 100 = 178 IQ. Average of the bounds is 164 IQ. Of  course, if Jobs was a young 4th grader then his IQ would be even higher.  Steve Jobs clearly had exceptional intelligence, regardless of what his  exact IQ score was. This makes sense, considering that Bill Gates, the other wunderkind, said 'Software is an IQ business.' This is taken from my article for Psychology Today: http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/finding-the-next-einstein/201111/was-steve-jobs-smart-heck-yes

Forgive my English, but I would like to give my opinion. The answer is: there is no way to know. And whoever speaks a number will be lying - it will be no more than a mere chunk of numbers, written in some text as if it were something intellectual. Second answer: Is it important to know what a person's IQ is? Using metaphor, the important thing is not the number of colors you have, but what you do with them! A talented person, like the Italian artist Diego Fazio, can do incredible works with just a pencil. Similarly, a person with median IQ can be a great pro. Do not limit yourself to a mere paper to tell who you are or what you can do ... just do it!  If you are a healthy person, you, as a human being, have the potential to enter History, just do do at least one remarkable thing. There are multiple intelligences and they are like playing cards and each person has a set of these cards - the value of the cards depends on the context in which you find yourself and how each of us works these cards. Stanley Kubrick, Steve Jobs, Albert Einstein, and Thomas Edison are examples of people who failed in school and won in life. The latter was even called retarded by the professor and Einstein learned to speak late.

Steve Jobs was not the smartest, academically. But he was amazing at thinking theoretically and logically. He could think rationally and he could read people. He was very philosophical, something useful for an entrepreneur. He was also a spoiled kid, and he told people to do what he wanted, and it got done. If you look at all A students, they don't generally want to change the world, they think realistically. Average students genneraly don't care about their career until university. But students who have high grades and extracurricular in one or two subjects, tend to want to be something. Now, we don't know Jobs’ grades, but we do know that he was passionate about technology, at least after the apple 2. He was focused on tech. You could say that he was one of the students who got high grades and stuff in one subject. I would say that he had an IQ of around 130–140.

Forgive my English, but I would like to give my opinion. The answer is: there is no way to know. And whoever speaks a number will be lying - it will be no more than a mere chunk of numbers, written in some text as if it were something intellectual. Second answer: Is it important to know what a person's IQ is? Using metaphor, the important thing is not the number of colors you have, but what you do with them! A talented person, like the Italian artist Diego Fazio, can do incredible works with just a pencil. Similarly, a person with median IQ can be a great pro. Do not limit yourself to a mere paper to tell who you are or what you can do ... just do it! If you are a healthy person, you, as a human being, have the potential to enter History, just do do at least one remarkable thing. There are multiple intelligences and they are like playing cards and each person has a set of these cards - the value of the cards depends on the context in which you find yourself and how each of us works these cards. I sincerely doubt he ever wasted time taking an IQ test. That, it strikes me, would have been very out of character. Regard with much suspicion any answer that attempts to put a number on it.

I have two response questions for you: What do you really want to know when you ask about Job’s IQ? There must be something more to your query than just wanting a 3-digit number.How will your perception of the world change if someone gives you those 3 digits. Try this, for example: Job’s IQ was definitively measured as 178. I’ll give you a a few more significant figures: 178.14569. Did that help? Do you see the world more clearly now? If so, that’s great. Please share!
